Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 07:58PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:16AM by deborye When the surgeon removes lymph nodes from the axilla, the lymphatic system in your underarm is disrupted, leaving you at risk for lymphedema. Scarred lymphatic vessels which are thin, cord-like structures that look a bit like violin strings may also appear underneath the skin of your arm. Cording usually develops within a few weeks after surgery. These structures, although alarming, are essentially harmless and will disappear or actually "snap" on their own as you do your stretching exercises.

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 07:23AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:21AM by deborye I go to a breast care center in Woburn MA. I have been going there to have my mams since I was 42, I am now 59.  When I was dx in March of 2007, my BS ordered Bone Scan, CT, MRI, chest X-rays and tons of blood work.  Nothing found except for a cyst in my Pancreas which I probably had for a long time and did not know.  So that was followed with a MRI every 6 months for a few years, it is gone now.  I had mams every 6 months for almost 2 yrs and saw my onc every 4 months.  Now it is down to mams once a year with a follow up with BS right after.  I just had TM test done, all was normal except one, it was abnormal. My onc says not to worry because the others were in the normal range.  So I will have the blood work re-done in March with a few more liver function tests which I know are normal.  I have those test done every 6 months because of thyroid and cholestoral meds.
